sp.p: To-day a certain damsel was presented to her. Why now should I extol or commend her beauty to you, Antipho, since you yourself know how nice a judge of beauty I am? I have been smitten by her.

sp.speaker: ANTIPHO
sp.p: Do you say so?

sp.speaker: CHAEREA
sp.p: If you saw her, I am sure you would say she's exquisite. What need of many words? I fell in love with her. By good luck there was at our house a certain Eunuch, whom my brother had purchased for Thais, and he had not as yet been sent to her. On this occasion, Parmeno, our servant, made a suggestion to me, which I adopted.

sp.speaker: ANTIPHO
sp.p: What was it?

sp.speaker: CHAEREA
sp.p: Be quiet, and you shall hear the sooner; to change clothes with him, and order myself to be taken there in his stead.

sp.speaker: ANTIPHO
sp.p: What, instead of the Eunuch?

sp.speaker: CHAEREA
sp.p: The fact.

sp.speaker: ANTIPHO
sp.p: To receive what advantage, pray, from this plan?

sp.speaker: CHAEREA
sp.p: Do you ask? That I might see, hear, and be in company with her whom I loved, Antipho. Is that a slight motive, or a poor reason? I was presented to the woman. She, as soon as she received me, joyfully took me home to her house and intrusted the damsel----

sp.speaker: ANTIPHO
sp.p: To whom? To you?

sp.speaker: CHAEREA
sp.p: To me.

sp.speaker: ANTIPHO
sp.p: ironically. In perfect safety, at all events.

sp.speaker: CHAEREA
sp.p: She gave orders that no male was to come near her, and commanded me not to stir away from her; that I was to remain alone with her in the inner apartments.In the inner apartments: The "Gynecaea," or women's apartments, among the Greeks, always occupied the interior part of the house, which was most distant from the street, and there they were kept in great seclusion. Looking bashfully on the ground, I nodded assent.

sp.speaker: ANTIPHO
sp.p: ironically. Poor fellow!

sp.speaker: CHAEREA
sp.p: continuing. "I am going out," said she, "to dinner." She took her maids with her; a few novices of girlsA few novices of girls: These "noviciae" were young slaves recently bought, and intended to be trained to the calling of a Courtesan. remained, to be about her. These immediately made preparations for her to bathe. I urged them to make haste. While preparations were being made, the damsel sat in a room looking up at a certain painting,At a certain painting: See the story of Jupiter and Danaë, the daughter of Acrisius, king of Argos, in the Metamorphoses of Ovid, B. iv., l. 610. Pictures of Venus and Adonis, and of Jupiter and Ganymede, are mentioned in the Menaechmi of Plautus; l. 144, and paintings on the walls are also mentioned in the Mostellaria of Plautus, l. 821, where Tranio tries to impose upon Theuropides by pretending to point out a picture of a crow between two vultures. in which was represented how JoveHow Jove: Donatus remarks here that this was "a very proper piece of furniture for the house of a Courtesan, giving an example of loose and mercenary Love, calculated to excite wanton thoughts, and at the same time hinting to the young lover that he must make his way to the bosom of his mistress, like Jupiter to Danaë, in a shower of gold. Oh the avarice of harlots!" is said once to have sent a golden shower into the bosom of Danaë. I myself began to look at it as well, and as he had in former times played the like game, I felt extremely delighted that a God should change himself into money, and slily come through the tiles of another person's house, to deceive the fair one by means of a shower. But what God was this? He who shakes the most lofty temples of heaven with his thunders. Was I, a poor creature of a mortal,A poor creature of a mortal: "Homuncio." He uses this word the better to contrast his abject nature as a poor mortal with the majesty of Jupiter. St. Augustin refers to this passage. The preceding line is said by Donatus to be a parody on a passage by Ennius. not to do the same? Certainly, I was to do it, and without hesitation. While I was thinking over these matters with myself, the damsel meantime was fetched away to bathe; she went, bathed, and came back; after which they laid her on a couch. I stood waiting to see if they gave me any orders. One came up, "Here, Dorus," said she, "take this fan,Take this fan: As to the fans of the ancients, see the Trinummus of Plautus, l. 252, and the Note to the passage in Bohn's Translation. See also the Amours of Ovid, B. iii., El. 2, l. 38. and let her have a little air in this fashion, while we are bathing; when we have bathed, if you like, you may bathe too." With a demure air I took it.

sp.speaker: ANTIPHO
sp.p: Really, I should very much have liked to see that impudent face of yours just then, and what figure a great donkey like you made, holding a fan!

sp.speaker: CHAEREA
sp.p:
continuing. Hardly had she said this, when all, in a moment, betook themselves off: away they went to bathe, and chattered aloud;Chattered aloud: This line bears a strong resemblance to two lines found in Anstey's new Bath Guide:
"And how the young ladies all set up their clacks,
All the while an old woman was rubbing their backs." just as the way is when masters are absent. Meanwhile, sleep overtook the damsel; I slily looked askanceI slily looked askance: This way of looking aside, "limis," is mentioned in the Miles Gloriosus of Plautus, where Milphidippa tells Acroteleutium to look at the Captain sideways, "Aspicito limis," l. 1217; also in the Bacchides, l. 1131. Those familiar with the works of Hogarth will readily call to mind the picture of Bedlam in the Rake's Progress, where the young woman is looking askance through her fan at the madman in his cell. through the fan;Through the fan: This shows that the fan was probably one made of thin boards, and not of feathers. this way showing how: at the same time I looked round in all directions, to see whether all was quite safe. I saw that it was. I bolted the door.

sp.speaker: ANTIPHO
sp.p: What then?

sp.speaker: CHAEREA
sp.p: Eh? What then, you simpleton?

sp.speaker: ANTIPHO
sp.p: I own I am.

sp.speaker: CHAEREA
sp.p: Was I to let slip the opportunity offered me, so excellent, so short-lived,So short-lived: Colman has the following Note here: "Short indeed, considering the number of incidents, which, according to Chaerea's relation, are crowded into it. All the time allowed for this adventure is the short space between the departure of Thais and Thraso and the entrance of Chaerea; so that all this variety of business of sleeping, bathing, ravishing, &c., is dispatched during the two soliloquies of Antipho and Chaerea, and the short Scene between Chremes and Pythias. The truth is, that a very close adherence to the unities often drives the Poet into as great absurdities as the perfect violation of them." so longed for, so unexpected. In that case, i'faith, I really should have been the person I was pretending to be.

sp.speaker: ANTIPHO
sp.p: Troth, you certainly are in the right; but, meantime, what has been arranged about the club-entertainment?

sp.speaker: CHAEREA
sp.p: All's ready.

sp.speaker: ANTIPHO
sp.p: You are a clever hand; but where? At your house?

sp.speaker: CHAEREA
sp.p: No, at Discus's, our freedman.

sp.speaker: ANTIPHO
sp.p: That's a long way off.

sp.speaker: CHAEREA
sp.p: Then let's make so much the greater haste.

sp.speaker: ANTIPHO
sp.p: Change your dress.

sp.speaker: CHAEREA
sp.p: Where am I to change it? I'm at a loss; for at present I'm an exile from home; I'm afraid of my brother, lest he should be in-doors: and then again of my father, lest he should have returned from the country by this.

sp.speaker: ANTIPHO
sp.p: Let's go to my house; there is the nearest place for you to change.

sp.speaker: CHAEREA
sp.p: You say right. Let's be off; besides, I want to take counsel with you about this girl, by what means I may be able to secure the future possession of her.

sp.speaker: ANTIPHO
sp.p: Very well. (Exeunt.)

div2.stage: Enter DORIAS, with a casket in her hand.

sp.speaker: DORIAS
sp.p: to herself. So may the Gods bless me, but from what I have seen, I'm terribly afraid that this mad fellow will be guilty of some disturbance to-day or of some violence to Thais. For when this young man, the brother of the damsel, arrived, she begged the Captain to order him to be admitted; he immediately began to get into a passion, and yet didn't dare refuse; Thais still insisted that he would invite the man in. This she did for the sake of detaining him; because there was no opportunity just then of telling him what she wanted to disclose about her sister. He was invited in, and took his seat. Then she entered into discourse with him. But the Captain, fancying it was a rival brought before his very eyes, wanted in his turn to mortify her: "Hark you, boy," said he, "go fetch Pamphila, that she may amuse us here." She exclaimed, "At a banquet! Certainly not." The Captain still persisted to a downright quarrel. Meanwhile my mistress secretly took off her golden jewels,Took off her golden jewels: This was probably because it was contrary to the laws of Athens for a Courtesan to appear with gold or jewels in the street. Madame Dacier suggests another reason, in which there is some force, although it is ridiculed by Cooke. Thais may have supposed that the Captain, when irritated, might not have scrupled to take them away from her. Indeed, nothing would be more probable, than that he would be ready to take them by way of security for the return of the slave, whom he had thus, to no purpose, presented to her. In reference to the preceding line, we may remark that it was not customary among the Greeks for females of good character to appear at table with strangers. and gave them to me to take away: this is a sign, I'm sure, that she'll betake herself from there as soon as she possibly can. Goes into the house.

sp.speaker: PHAEDRIA
sp.p: to himself. While I was goingWhile I was going: Donatus remarks that here the Poet artfully finds a reason to bring Phaedria back again; as he at first with equal art sent him out of the way, to give probability to those incidents necessary to happen in his absence. into the country, I began on the road, as it mostly happens when there is any anxiety on the mind, to reflect with myself upon one thing after another, and upon every thing in the worst light. What need of words? While I was musing thus, inadvertently I passed my country-house. I had already got some distance from it, when I perceived this; I returned again, really feeling quite uneasy; when I came to the very turning that leads to the house, I came to a stop, and began to reason with myself; "What! must I stay here alone for two days without her? Well, and what then? It's nothing at all. What? Nothing at all? Well now, if I haven;t the privilege of touching her, am I not even to have that of seeing her? If I may not do the one, at least I may the other. Surely to love at a distanceAt a distance: "Extremâ lineâ." There have been many suggestions offered for the origin of this figurative expression. Some suggest that it alludes to the last or lowest stage of the supposed ladder of love; others that it refers to the first or elementary line traced by the student, when beginning to learn the art of painting. It is however more generally thought to be a metaphor taken from the chariotraces in the Circus, where, in going round the turning-place, he who was nearest was said "currere in primâ lineâ;" the next, "in secundâ;" and so on to the last, who took the widest range, and was said to run "in extremâ lineâ." even, is better than nothing at all." I purposely passed the house. But how's this, that Pythias is suddenly hurrying out in such a fright? Stands apart.

div2.stage: Enter PYTHIAS and DORIAS in haste from the house of THAIS.

sp.speaker: PYTHIAS
sp.p: aloud. Where, wretch that I am, shall I find this wicked and impious fellow? Or where look for him? That he should dare to commit so audacious a crime as this! I'm ruined outright!

sp.speaker: PHAEDRIA
sp.p: apart. I dread what this may be.

sp.speaker: PYTHIAS
sp.p: Besides, too, the villain, after he had abused the girl, rent all the poor thing's clothes, and tore her hair as well.

sp.speaker: PHAEDRIA
sp.p: apart, in surprise. Ha!

sp.speaker: PYTHIAS
sp.p: If he were just now in my reach, how eagerly would I fly at that villain's eyes with my nails!

sp.speaker: PHAEDRIA
sp.p: apart. Really I can't imagine what disturbance has happened to us at home in my absence. I'll accost them. Going up to them. What's the matter? Why in such haste? Or whom are you looking for, Pythias?

sp.speaker: PYTHIAS
sp.p: Why, Phaedria, whom should I be looking for? Away with you, as you deserve, with such fine presents of yours.

sp.speaker: PHAEDRIA
sp.p: What is the matter?

sp.speaker: PYTHIAS
sp.p: What, do you ask? The Eunuch you gave us, what confusion he has caused. He has ravished the girl whom the Captain made present of to my mistress.

sp.speaker: PHAEDRIA
sp.p: What is it you say?

sp.speaker: PYTHIAS
sp.p: I'm ruined outright!

sp.speaker: PHAEDRIA
sp.p: You are drunk.

sp.speaker: PYTHIAS
sp.p: I wish that they were so, who wish ill to me.

sp.speaker: DORIAS
sp.p: Oh, prithee, my dear Pythias, what a monstrous thing this is!

sp.speaker: PHAEDRIA
sp.p: You are out of your senses. How could a Eunuch possibly do this?

sp.speaker: PYTHIAS
sp.p: I know nothing about him: as to what he has done, the thing speaks for itself. The girl is in tears; and when you ask her what's the matter, she does not dare tell. But he, a precious fellow, is nowhere to be seen. To my sorrow I suspect too, that when he took himself off he carried something away from the house.

sp.speaker: PHAEDRIA
sp.p: I can not enough wonder, whither this varlet can possibly have betaken himself to any distance from here; unless perhaps he has returned home to our house.

sp.speaker: PYTHIAS
sp.p: Pray, go and see whether he is there.

sp.speaker: PHAEDRIA
sp.p: I'll let you know immediately. Goes into the house of LACHES.

sp.speaker: DORIAS
sp.p: Ruined outright! Prithee, my dear, I never did so much as hear of a deed so abominable!

sp.speaker: PYTHIAS
sp.p: Why, faith, I had heard that they were extremely fond of the women, but were incapable; unfortunately what has happened never came into my mind; otherwise I should have shut him up somewhere, and not have intrusted the girl to him.

div2.stage: Enter PHAEDRIA from the house of LACHES, with DORUS in CHAEREA'S clothes.

sp.speaker: PHAEDRIA
sp.p: dragging him out. Come out, you villain! What, do you lag behind, you runaway? Out with you, you sorry bargain!

sp.speaker: DORUS
sp.p: crying out. Mercy, I do entreat you!

sp.speaker: PHAEDRIA
sp.p: Oh, do look at that! How the villain distorts his face. What means your coming back hither? Why this change of dress? What have you to say? If I had delayed a moment, Pythias, I shouldn't have found him at home: he had just prepared, in this fashion, for flight. Pointing at his dress.

sp.speaker: PYTHIAS
sp.p: Have you caught the fellow, pray?

sp.speaker: PHAEDRIA
sp.p: Caught him, why not?

sp.speaker: PYTHIAS
sp.p: O well done!

sp.speaker: DORIAS
sp.p: Upon my faith that really is capital!

sp.speaker: PYTHIAS
sp.p: Where is he?

sp.speaker: PHAEDRIA
sp.p: Do you ask the question? Don't you see him? Pointing to the EUNUCH.

sp.speaker: PYTHIAS
sp.p: staring about. See whom, pray?

sp.speaker: PHAEDRIA
sp.p: This fellow, to be sure pointing.

sp.speaker: PYTHIAS
sp.p: What person is this?

sp.speaker: PHAEDRIA
sp.p: The same that was brought to your house to-day.

sp.speaker: PYTHIAS
sp.p: Not one of our people has ever beheld this person with her eyes, Phaedria.

sp.speaker: PHAEDRIA
sp.p: Not beheld him?

sp.speaker: PYTHIAS
sp.p: Prithee, did you fancy that this was he who was brought to our house?

sp.speaker: PHAEDRIA
sp.p: Why, I had no other.

sp.speaker: PYTHIAS
sp.p: O dear! this one really isn't to be compared with the other. He was of a handsome and genteel appearance.

sp.speaker: PHAEDRIA
sp.p: He seemed so, just then, because he was decked out in party-colored clothes:In party-colored clothes: It was the custom to dress Eunuchs in party-colored clothes of bright hue. Most probably it was from them that the "motley" descended to the fools and buffoons of the Middle Ages. now he appears ugly, for this reason--because he hasn't got them on.

sp.speaker: PYTHIAS
sp.p: Prithee, do hold your tongue; as though indeed the difference was so trifling. A young man was brought to our house to-day, whom, really, Phaedria, you would have liked to look upon. This is a withered, antiquated, lethargic, old fellow, with a speckled complexion.With a speckled complexion: "Colore stellionino;" probably having spots or freckles on his face like a "stellio" or "lizard."

sp.speaker: PHAEDRIA
sp.p: starting. Hah! What tale is this? You'll so befool me that I sha'n't know what I bought. To DORUS. How now, sirrah, did I not buy you?

sp.speaker: DORUS
sp.p: You did buy me.

sp.speaker: PYTHIAS
sp.p: Bid him answer me in my turn.

sp.speaker: PHAEDRIA
sp.p: Question him.

sp.speaker: PYTHIAS
sp.p: to DORUS. Did you come here to-day to our house? DORUS shakes his head. He says, no. But it was the other one that came, about sixteen years of age; whom Parmeno brought with him.

sp.speaker: PHAEDRIA
sp.p: to DORUS. Well now, in the first place tell me this, where did you get that dress that you have on? What, are you silent? Monster of a fellow, are you not going to speak? Shakes him.

sp.speaker: DORUS
sp.p: Chaerea came.

sp.speaker: PHAEDRIA
sp.p: What, my brother?

sp.speaker: DORUS
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: PHAEDRIA
sp.p: When?

sp.speaker: DORUS
sp.p: To-day.

sp.speaker: PHAEDRIA
sp.p: How long since?

sp.speaker: DORUS
sp.p: Just now.

sp.speaker: PHAEDRIA
sp.p: With whom?

sp.speaker: DORUS
sp.p: With Parmeno.

sp.speaker: PHAEDRIA
sp.p: Did you know him before?

sp.speaker: DORUS
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: PHAEDRIA
sp.p: How did you know he was my brother?

sp.speaker: DORUS
sp.p: Parmeno said he was. He gave me these clothes.

sp.speaker: PHAEDRIA
sp.p: I'm undone!

sp.speaker: DORUS
sp.p: He himself put on mine; afterward, they both went out together.

sp.speaker: PYTHIAS
sp.p: Now are you quite satisfied that I am sober, and that we have told you no falsehood? Is it now sufficiently evident that the girl has been ravished?

sp.speaker: PHAEDRIA
sp.p: Avaunt, you beast, do you believe what he says?

sp.speaker: PYTHIAS
sp.p: What is there to believe? The thing speaks for itself.

sp.speaker: PHAEDRIA
sp.p: apart to DORUS. Step aside a little this way. Do you hear? DORUS steps aside. A little further still. That will do. Now tell me this once more; did Chaerea take your clothes off you?

sp.speaker: DORUS
sp.p: He did.

sp.speaker: PHAEDRIA
sp.p: And did he put them on?

sp.speaker: DORUS
sp.p: He did.

sp.speaker: PHAEDRIA
sp.p: And was he brought here instead of you?

sp.speaker: DORUS
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: PHAEDRIA
sp.p: Great Jupiter! O wicked and audacious fellow!

sp.speaker: PYTHIAS
sp.p: Woe unto me! Now at last will you believe that we have been insulted in a disgraceful manner?

sp.speaker: PHAEDRIA
sp.p: It is no wonder that you believe what the fellow says. Aside. What I'm to do I know not. Aside to DORUS. Hark you, deny it all again. Aloud. Can I not this day extract the truth from you? Did you really see my brother Chaerea?

sp.speaker: DORUS
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: PHAEDRIA
sp.p: He can't be brought to confess without being punished, I see: follow me this way. At one moment he affirms, at another denies. Aside. Ask pardon of me.

sp.speaker: DORUS
sp.p: Indeed, I do entreat you, Phaedria.

sp.speaker: PHAEDRIA
sp.p: kicking him. Be off in-doors.

sp.speaker: DORUS
sp.p: Oh! oh!

sp.speaker: PHAEDRIA
sp.p: aside. How in any other fashion to get decently out of this I don't know; for really it's all up with me. Aloud, with pretended indignation. Will you be trifling with me even here, you knave? Follows DORUS into the house.

sp.speaker: PYTHIAS
sp.p: I'm as certain that this is the contrivance of Parmeno as that I'm alive.

sp.speaker: DORIAS
sp.p: So it is, no doubt.

sp.speaker: PYTHIAS
sp.p: I'faith, I'll find out a method to-day to be even with him. But now, what do you think ought to be done, Dorias?

sp.speaker: DORIAS
sp.p: Do you mean with regard to this girl?

sp.speaker: PYTHIAS
sp.p: Yes; whether I ought to mention it or be silent?

sp.speaker: DORIAS
sp.p: Upon my word, if you are prudent, you won't know what you do know, either about the Eunuch or the girl's misfortune. By this method you'll both rid yourself of all perplexity, and have done a service to her.Have done a service to her: Though some would have "illi" here to refer to the damsel, and others again to Phaedria, it is pretty clear that Madame Dacier is right in suggesting that Thais is the person meant. Say this only, that Dorus has run away.

sp.speaker: PYTHIAS
sp.p: I'll do so.

sp.speaker: DORIAS
sp.p: But don't I see Chremes? Thais will be here just now.

sp.speaker: PYTHIAS
sp.p: Why so?

sp.speaker: DORIAS
sp.p: Because when I came away from there, a quarrel had just commenced between them.

sp.speaker: PYTHIAS
sp.p: Take in these golden trinkets; I shall learn from him what's the matter. DORIAS takes the casket into the house.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: Heyday! upon my faith, I've been bamboozled: the wine that I've drunk has got the upper hand. But, so long as I was reclining, how extremely sober I did seem to myself to be; when I got up, neither feet nor senses were quite equal to their duty.

sp.speaker: PYTHIAS
sp.p: Chremes!

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: turning round. Who's that? What, Pythias; dear me, how much more charming you now seem to me than a short time since!

sp.speaker: PYTHIAS
sp.p: Troth now, you are much more merry, that's certain.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: Upon my faith, it is a true saying, that "Venus grows cold without Ceres and Bacchus." But has Thais got here long before me?

sp.speaker: PYTHIAS
sp.p: Has she already come away from the Captain's?

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: A long time ago; an age since. There has been a most violent quarrel between them.

sp.speaker: PYTHIAS
sp.p: Did she say nothing about you following her?

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: Nothing at all; only, on going away, she gave me a nod.

sp.speaker: PYTHIAS
sp.p: Well now, wasn't that enough?

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: Why, I didn't know that she meant that, until the Captain gave me an explanation, because I was dull of comprehension; for he bundled me out of the house. But look, here she is; I wonder how it was I got here before her.

sp.speaker: THAIS
sp.p: to herself. I really do believe that he'll be here presently, to force her away from me. Let him come; but if he touches her with a single finger, that instant his eyes shall be torn out. I can put up with his impertinences and his high-sounding words, as long as they remain words: but if they are turned into realities, he shall get a drubbing.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: Thais, I've been here some time.

sp.speaker: THAIS
sp.p: O my dear Chremes, you are the very person I was wanting. Are you aware that this quarrel took place on your account, and that the whole of this affair, in fact, bore reference to yourself?

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: To me? How so, pray?

sp.speaker: THAIS
sp.p: Because, while I've been doing my best to recover and restore your sister to you, this and a great deal more like it I've had to put up with.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: Where is she?

sp.speaker: THAIS
sp.p: At home, at my house.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: starting. Hah!

sp.speaker: THAIS
sp.p: What's the matter? She has been brought up in a manner worthy of yourself and of her.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: What is it you say?

sp.speaker: THAIS
sp.p: That which is the fact. Her I present to you, nor do I ask of you any return for her.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: Thanks are both felt and shall be returned in such way, Thais, as you deserve.

sp.speaker: THAIS
sp.p: But still, take care, Chremes, that you don't lose her, before you receive her from me; for it is she, whom the Captain is now coming to take away from me by force. Do you go, Pythias, and bring out of the house the casket with the tokens.Casket with the tokens: It was the custom with the ancients when they exposed their children, to leave with them some pledge or token of value, that they might afterward be recognized by means of them. The catastrophes of the Curculio, the Rudens, and other Plays of Plautus, are brought about by taking advantage of this circumstance. The reasons for using these tokens will be stated in a future Note.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: looking down the side Scene. Don't you see him, Thais?

sp.speaker: PYTHIAS
sp.p: to THAIS. Where is it put?

sp.speaker: THAIS
sp.p: In the clothes' chest. Tiresome creature, why do you delay? PYTHIAS goes into the house.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: What a large body of troops the Captain is bringing with him against you. Bless me!

sp.speaker: THAIS
sp.p: Prithee, are you frightened, my dear sir?

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: Get out with you. What, I frightened? There's not a man alive less so.

sp.speaker: THAIS
sp.p: Then now is the time to prove it.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: Why, I wonder what sort of a man you take me to be.

sp.speaker: THAIS
sp.p: Nay, and consider this too; the person that you have to deal with is a foreigner;Is a foreigner: And therefore the more unlikely to obtain redress from an Athenian tribunal. See the Andria, l. 811, and the Note to the passage. of less influence than you, less known, and one that has fewer friends here.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: I'm aware of that; but it's foolish to run the risk of what you are able to avoid. I had rather we should prevent it, than, having received an injury, avenge ourselves upon him. Do you go in and fasten the door, while I run across hence to the Forum; I should like us to have the aid of some legal adviser in this disturbance. Moves, as if going.

sp.speaker: THAIS
sp.p: holding him. Stay.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: Let me go, I'll be here presently.

sp.speaker: THAIS
sp.p: There's no occasion, Chremes. Only say that she is your sister, and that you lost her when a little girl, and have now recognized her; then show the tokens. Re-enter PYTHIAS from the house, with the trinkets.

sp.speaker: PYTHIAS
sp.p: giving them to THAIS. Here they are.

sp.speaker: THAIS
sp.p: giving them to CHREMES. Take them. If he offers any violence, summon the fellow to justice; do you understand me?

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: Perfectly.

sp.speaker: THAIS
sp.p: Take care and say this with presence of mind.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: I'll take care.

sp.speaker: THAIS
sp.p: Gather up your cloak. Aside. Undone! the very person whom I've provided as a champion, wants one himself. They all go into the house.

div2.stage: Enter THRASO, followed by GNATHO, SANGA, and other Attendants.

sp.speaker: THRASO
sp.p: Am I to submit, Gnatho, to such a glaring affront as this being put upon me? I'd die sooner. Simalio, Donax, Syriscus, follow me! First, I'll storm the house.

sp.speaker: GNATHO
sp.p: Quite right.

sp.speaker: THRASO
sp.p: I'll carry off the girl.

sp.speaker: GNATHO
sp.p: Very good.

sp.speaker: THRASO
sp.p: I'll give her own self a mauling.

sp.speaker: GNATHO
sp.p: Very proper.

sp.speaker: THRASO
sp.p: arranging the men. Advance hither to the main body, Donax, with your crowbar; you, Simalio, to the left wing; you, Syriscus, to the right. Bring up the rest; where's the centurion Sanga, and his manipleAnd his maniple: We learn from the Fasti of Ovid, B. iii., l. 117-8, that in early times the Roman armies carried bundles or wisps of hay upon poles by way of standards. "A long pole used to bear the elevated wisps, from which circumstance the manipular soldier derives his name." It appears from this passage, and from other authors, that to every troop of one hundred men a "manipulus" or wisp of hay (so called from "manum implere," to "fill the hand," as being "a handful"), was assigned as a standard, and hence in time the company itself obtained the name of "manipulus," and the soldier, a member of it, was called "manipularis." The "centurio," or "leader of a hundred," was the commanding officer of the "manipulus." of rogues?

sp.speaker: SANGA
sp.p: coming forward. See, here he is.

sp.speaker: THRASO
sp.p: What, you booby, do you think of fighting with a dish-clout,With a dish-clout: "Peniculo." This word meant a sponge fastened to a stick, or the tail of a fox or an ox, which was used as dusters or dish-clouts are at the present day for cleaning tables, dishes, or even shoes. See the Menaechmi of Plautus, ver. 77 and 391. to be bringing that here?

sp.speaker: SANGA
sp.p: What, I? I knew the valor of the general, and the prowess of the soldiers; and that this could not possibly go on without bloodshed; how was I to wipe the wounds?

sp.speaker: THRASO
sp.p: Where are the others?

sp.speaker: SANGA
sp.p: Plague on you, what others? Sannio is the only one left on guard at home.

sp.speaker: THRASO
sp.p: to GNATHO. Do you draw up your men in battle order; I'll be behind the second rank;Be behind the second rank: "Post principia." The Captain, with that discretion which is the better part of valor, chooses the safest place in his army. The "principes" originally fought in the van, fronting the enemy, and behind them were the "hastati" and the "triarii." In later times the "hastati" faced the enemy, and the "principes" were placed in the middle, between them and the "triarii;" but though no longer occupying the front place, they still retained the name. Thraso, then, places himself behind the middle line. from that position I'll give the word to all. Takes his place behind the second rank.

sp.speaker: GNATHO
sp.p: aside. That's showing prudence; as soon as he has drawn them up, he secures a retreat for himself.

sp.speaker: THRASO
sp.p: pointing to the arrangements. This is just the way Pyrrhus used to proceed.Pyrrhus used to proceed: He attempts to defend his cowardice by the example of Pyrrhus, the powerful antagonist of the Romans, and one of the greatest generals of antiquity. He might have more correctly cited the example of Xerxes, who, according to Justin, did occupy that position in his army. CHREMES and THAIS appear above at a window.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: Do you see, Thais, what plan he is upon? Assuredly, that advice of mine about closing the door was good.

sp.speaker: THAIS
sp.p: He who now seems to you to be a hero, is in reality a mere vaporer; don't be alarmed.

sp.speaker: THRASO
sp.p: to GNATHO. What seems best to you?

sp.speaker: GNATHO
sp.p: I could very muchI could very much: Although Vollbehr gives these words to Gnatho, yet, judging from the context, and the words "ex occulto," and remembering that Thais and Chremes are up at the window, there is the greatest probability that these are really the words of Thais addressed aside to Chremes. like a sling to be given you just now, that you might pelt them from here on the sly at a distance; they would be taking to flight.

sp.speaker: THRASO
sp.p: to GNATHO. But look pointing, I see Thais there herself.

sp.speaker: GNATHO
sp.p: How soon are we to fall to?

sp.speaker: THRASO
sp.p: Hold holding him back; it behooves a prudent person to make trial of every thing before arms. How do you know but that she may do what I bid her without compulsion?

sp.speaker: GNATHO
sp.p: Ye Gods, by our trust in you, what a thing it is to be wise! I never come near you but what I go away from you the wiser.

sp.speaker: THRASO
sp.p: Thais, in the first place, answer me this. When I presented you that girl, did you not say that you would give yourself up to me alone for some days to come?

sp.speaker: THAIS
sp.p: Well, what then?

sp.speaker: THRASO
sp.p: Do you ask the question? You, who have been and brought your lover under my very eyes? What business had you with him? With him, too, you clandestinely betook yourself away from me.

sp.speaker: THAIS
sp.p: I chose to do so.

sp.speaker: THRASO
sp.p: Then give me back Pamphila; unless you had rather she were taken away by force.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: Give her back to you, or you lay hands upon her? Of all the----

sp.speaker: GNATHO
sp.p: Ha! What are you about? Hold your tongue.

sp.speaker: THRASO
sp.p: What do you mean? Am I not to touch my own?

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: Your own, indeed, you gallows-bird!You gallows-bird: "Furcifer;" literally, "bearer of the furca."

sp.speaker: GNATHO
sp.p: to CHREMES. Have a care, if you please. You don't know what kind of man you are abusing now.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: to GNATHO. Won't you be off from here? Do you know how matters stand with you? If you cause any disturbance here to-day, I'll make you remember the place, and day, and me too, for the rest of your life.

sp.speaker: GNATHO
sp.p: I pity you, who are making so great a man as this your enemy.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: I'll break your head this instant if you are not off.

sp.speaker: GNATHO
sp.p: Do you really say so, puppy? Is it that you are at?

sp.speaker: THRASO
sp.p: to CHREMES. What fellow are you? What do you mean? What business have you with her?

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: I'll let you know: in the first place, I assert that she is a freeborn woman.

sp.speaker: THRASO
sp.p: starting. Ha!

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: A citizen of Attica.

sp.speaker: THRASO
sp.p: Whew!

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: My own sister.

sp.speaker: THRASO
sp.p: Brazen face!

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: Now, therefore, Captain, I give you warning; don't you use any violence toward her. Thais, I'm going to Sophrona, the nurse, that I may bring her here and show her these tokens.

sp.speaker: THRASO
sp.p: What! Are you to prevent me from touching what's my own?

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: I will prevent it, I tell you.

sp.speaker: GNATHO
sp.p: to THRASO. Do you hear him? He is convicting himself of theft. Is not that enough for you?

sp.speaker: THRASO
sp.p: Do you say the same, Thais?

sp.speaker: THAIS
sp.p: Go, find some one to answer you. She and CHREMES go away from the window.

sp.speaker: THRASO
sp.p: to GNATHO. What are we to do now?

sp.speaker: GNATHO
sp.p: Why, go back again: she'll soon be with you, of her own accord, to entreat forgiveness.

sp.speaker: THRASO
sp.p: Do you think so?

sp.speaker: GNATHO
sp.p: Certainly, yes. I know the disposition of women: when you will, they won't; when you won't, they set their hearts upon you of their own inclination.

sp.speaker: THRASO
sp.p: You judge right.

sp.speaker: GNATHO
sp.p: Shall I dismiss the army then?

sp.speaker: THRASO
sp.p: Whenever you like.

sp.speaker: GNATHO
sp.p: Sanga, as befits gallant soldiers,As befits gallant soldiers: Beaumont and Fletcher not improbably had this scene in view in their picture of the mob regiment in Philaster. The ragged regiment which Shakspeare places under the commend of Falstaff was not very unlike it, nor that which owned the valiant Bombastes Furioso as its Captain. take care in your turn to remember your homes and hearths.

sp.speaker: SANGA
sp.p: My thoughts have been for some time among the sauce-pans.

sp.speaker: GNATHO
sp.p: You are a worthy fellow.

sp.speaker: THRASO
sp.p: putting himself at their head. You follow me this way. (Exeunt omnes.)

div2.stage: Enter THAIS from her house, followed by PYTHIAS.

sp.speaker: THAIS
sp.p: What! do you persist, hussy, in talking ambiguously to me? "I do know;" "I don't know;" "he has gone off;" "I have heard;" "I wasn't there." Don't you mean to tell me plainly, whatever it is? The girl in tears, with her garments torn, is mute; the Eunuch is off: for what reason? What has happened? Won't you speak?

sp.speaker: PYTHIAS
sp.p: Wretch that I am, what am I to say to you? They declare that he was not a Eunuch.

sp.speaker: THAIS
sp.p: What was he then?

sp.speaker: PYTHIAS
sp.p: That Chaerea.

sp.speaker: THAIS
sp.p: What Chaerea?

sp.speaker: PYTHIAS
sp.p: That stripling, the brother of Phaedria.

sp.speaker: THAIS
sp.p: What's that you say, you hag?

sp.speaker: PYTHIAS
sp.p: And I am satisfied of it.

sp.speaker: THAIS
sp.p: Pray, what business had he at my house? What brought him there?

sp.speaker: PYTHIAS
sp.p: I don't know; unless, as I suppose, he was in love with Pamphila.

sp.speaker: THAIS
sp.p: Alas! to my confusion, unhappy woman that I am, I'm undone, if what you tell me is true. Is it about this that the girl is crying?

sp.speaker: PYTHIAS
sp.p: I believe so.

sp.speaker: THAIS
sp.p: How say you, you arch-jade? Did I not warn you about this very thing, when I was going away from here?

sp.speaker: PYTHIAS
sp.p: What could I do? Just as you ordered, she was intrusted to his care only.

sp.speaker: THAIS
sp.p: Hussy, I've been intrusting the sheep to the wolf. I'm quite ashamed to have been imposed upon in this way. What sort of man was he?

sp.speaker: PYTHIAS
sp.p: Hush! hush! mistress, pray; we are all right. Here we have the very man.

sp.speaker: THAIS
sp.p: Where is he?

sp.speaker: PYTHIAS
sp.p: Why there, to the left. Don't you see?

sp.speaker: THAIS
sp.p: I see.

sp.speaker: PYTHIAS
sp.p: Order him to be seized as quickly as possible.

sp.speaker: THAIS
sp.p: What can we do to him, simpleton?

sp.speaker: PYTHIAS
sp.p: What do to him, do you ask? Pray, do look at him; if his face doesn't seem an impudent one.

sp.speaker: THAIS
sp.p: Not at all.

sp.speaker: PYTHIAS
sp.p: Besides, what effrontery he has.

div2.stage: Enter CHAEREA, in the EUNUCH'S dress, on the other side of the stage.

sp.speaker: CHAEREA
sp.p: to himself. At Antipho's,At Antipho's: Madame Decier here observes that Chaerea assigns very natural reasons for not having changed his dress; in which the art of Terence is evident, since the sequel of the Play makes it absolutely necessary that Chaerea should appear again before Thais in the habit which he wore while in the house. both of them, father and mother, just as if on purpose, were at home, so that I couldn't any way get in, but that they must have seen me. In the mean time, while I was standing before the door, a certain acquaintance of mine was coming full upon me. When I espied him, I took to my heels as fast as I could down a narrow unfrequented alley; thence again to another, and thence to another; thus have I been most dreadfully harassed with running about, that no one might recognize me. But isn't this Thais that I see? It is she. I'm at a stand. What shall I do? But what need I care? What can she do to me?

sp.speaker: THAIS
sp.p: to PYTHIAS. Let's accost him. To CHAEREA. Good Mister Dorus, welcome; tell me, have you been running away?

sp.speaker: CHAEREA
sp.p: Madam, I did so.

sp.speaker: THAIS
sp.p: Are you quite pleased with it?

sp.speaker: CHAEREA
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: THAIS
sp.p: Do you fancy that you'll get off with impunity?

sp.speaker: CHAEREA
sp.p: Forgive this one fault; if I'm ever guilty of another, then kill me.

sp.speaker: THAIS
sp.p: Were you in fear of my severity?

sp.speaker: CHAEREA
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: THAIS
sp.p: No? What then?

sp.speaker: CHAEREA
sp.p: pointing at PYTHIAS. I was afraid of her, lest she might be accusing me to you.

sp.speaker: THAIS
sp.p: What had you done?

sp.speaker: CHAEREA
sp.p: A mere trifle.

sp.speaker: PYTHIAS
sp.p: Come now, a trifle, you impudent fellow. Does this appear a trifle to you, to ravish a virgin, a citizen?

sp.speaker: CHAEREA
sp.p: I took her for my fellow-servant.

sp.speaker: PYTHIAS
sp.p: Fellow-servant? I can hardly restrain myself from flying at his hair. A miscreant! Even of his own free will he comes to make fun of us.

sp.speaker: THAIS
sp.p: to PYTHIAS. Won't you begone from here, you mad woman?

sp.speaker: PYTHIAS
sp.p: Why so? Really, I do believe I should be something in this hang-dog's debt, if I were to do so; especially as he owns that he is your servant.

sp.speaker: THAIS
sp.p: We'll pass that by. Chaerea, you have behaved unworthily of yourself; for if I am deserving in the highest degree of this affront, still it is unbecoming of you to be guilty of it. And, upon my faith, I do not know what method now to adopt about this girl: you have so confounded all my plans, that I can not possibly return her to her friends in such a manner as is befitting and as I had intended; in order that, by this means, I might, Chaerea, do a real service to myself.

sp.speaker: CHAEREA
sp.p: But now, from henceforth, I hope, Thais, that there will be lasting good-will between us. Many a time, from some affair of this kind and from a bad beginning, great friendships have sprung up. What if some Divinity has willed this?

sp.speaker: THAIS
sp.p: I'faith, for my own part I both take it in that view and wish to do so.

sp.speaker: CHAEREA
sp.p: Yes, prithee, do so. Be sure of this one thing, that I did not do it for the sake of affronting you, but in consequence of passion.

sp.speaker: THAIS
sp.p: I understand, and, i'faith, for that reason do I now the more readily forgive you. I am not, Chaerea, of a disposition so ungentle, or so inexperienced, as not to know what is the power of love.

sp.speaker: CHAEREA
sp.p: So may the Deities kindly bless me, Thais; I am now smitten with you as well.

sp.speaker: PYTHIAS
sp.p: Then, i'faith, mistress, I foresee you must have a care of him.

sp.speaker: CHAEREA
sp.p: I would not dare----

sp.speaker: PYTHIAS
sp.p: I won't trust you at all in any thing.

sp.speaker: THAIS
sp.p: to PYTHIAS. Do have done.

sp.speaker: CHAEREA
sp.p: Now I entreat you that you will be my assistant in this affair. I intrust and commit myself to your care; I take you, Thais, as my protectress; I implore you; I shall die if I don't have her for my wife.

sp.speaker: THAIS
sp.p: But if your father should say any thing----

sp.speaker: CHAEREA
sp.p: Oh, he'll consent, I'm quite sure of that, if she is only a citizen.

sp.speaker: THAIS
sp.p: If you will wait a little, the brother himself of the young woman will be here presently; he has gone to fetch the nurse, who brought her up when a little child; you yourself, shall be present Chaerea, at his recognition of her.

sp.speaker: CHAEREA
sp.p: I certainly will stay.

sp.speaker: THAIS
sp.p: In the mean time, until he comes, would you prefer that we should wait for him in the house, rather than here before the door?

sp.speaker: CHAEREA
sp.p: Why yes, I should like it much.

sp.speaker: PYTIH.
sp.p: to THAIS. Prithee, what are you going to do?

sp.speaker: THAIS
sp.p: Why, what's the matter?

sp.speaker: PYTHIAS
sp.p: Do you ask? Do you think of admitting him after this into your house?

sp.speaker: THAIS
sp.p: Why not?

sp.speaker: PYTHIAS
sp.p: Trust my word for it, he'll be creating some new disturbance.

sp.speaker: THAIS
sp.p: O dear, prithee, do hold your tongue.

sp.speaker: PYTHIAS
sp.p: You seem to me to be far from sensible of his assurance.

sp.speaker: CHAEREA
sp.p: I'll not do any thing, Pythias.

sp.speaker: PYTHIAS
sp.p: Upon my faith, I don't believe you, Chaerea, except in case you are not trusted.

sp.speaker: CHAEREA
sp.p: Nay but, Pythias, do you be my keeper.

sp.speaker: PYTHIAS
sp.p: Upon my faith, I would neither venture to give any thing to you to keep, nor to keep you myself: away with you!

sp.speaker: THAIS
sp.p: Most opportunely the brother himself is coming.

sp.speaker: CHAEREA
sp.p: I'faith, I'm undone. Prithee, let's be gone in-doors, Thais. I don't want him to see me in the street with this dress on.

sp.speaker: THAIS
sp.p: For what reason, pray? Because you are ashamed?

sp.speaker: CHAEREA
sp.p: Just so.

sp.speaker: PYTHIAS
sp.p: Just so? But the young woman----

sp.speaker: THAIS
sp.p: Go first; I'll follow. You stay here, Pythias, that you may show Chremes in. THAIS and CHAEREA go into the house.

sp.speaker: PYTHIAS
sp.p: to herself. Well! what now can suggest itself to my mind? What, I wonder, in order that I may repay the favor to that villain who palmed this fellow off upon us?

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: Really, do bestir yourself more quickly, nurse.

sp.speaker: SOPHRONA
sp.p: I am bestirring.

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: So I see; but you don't stir forward.

sp.speaker: PYTHIAS
sp.p: to CHREMES. Have you yet shown the tokens to the nurse?

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: All of them.

sp.speaker: PYTHIAS
sp.p: Prithee, what does she say? Does she recognize them?

sp.speaker: CHREMES
sp.p: Yes, with a full recollection of them.

sp.speaker: PYTHIAS
sp.p: Upon my faith, you do bring good news; for I really wish well to this young woman. Go in-doors: my mistress has been for some time expecting you at home. CHREMES and SOPHRONA go into THAIS'S house. But look, yonder I espy that worthy fellow, Parmeno, coming: just see, for heaven's sake, how leisurely he moves along. I hope I have it in my power to torment him after my own fashion. I'll go in-doors, that I may know for certain about the discovery; afterward I'll come out, and give this villain a terrible fright. Goes into the house.

sp.speaker: PARMENO
sp.p: to himself. I've just come back to see what Chaerea has been doing here. If he has managed the affair with dexterity, ye Gods, by our trust in you, how great and genuine applause will Parmeno obtain! For not to mention that a passion, full of difficulty and expense, with which he was smitten for a virgin, belonging to an extortionate courtesan, I've found means of satisfying for him, without molestation, without outlay, and without cost; then, this other point-that is really a thing that I consider my crowning merit, to have found out the way by which a young man may be enabled to learn the dispositions and manners of courtesans, so that by knowing them betimes, he may detest them ever after. PYTHIAS enters from the house unperceived. For while they are out of doors, nothing seems more cleanly, nothing more neat or more elegant; and when they dine with a gallant, they pick daintily about:Pick daintily about: He seems here to reprehend the same practice against which Ovid warns his fair readers, in his Art of Love, B. iii. l. 75. He says, "Do not first take food at home," when about to go to an entertainment. Westerhovius seems to think that "ligurio" means, not to "pick daintily," but "to be fond of good eating;" and refers to the Bacchides of Plautus as portraying courtesans of the "ligurient" kind, and finds another specimen in Bacchis in: the Heautontimorumenos. to see the filth, the dirtiness, the neediness of these women; how sluttish they are when at home, and how greedy after victuals; in what a fashion they devour the black bread with yesterday's broth:--to know all this, is salvation to a young man.< Enter PYTHIAS from the house.

sp.speaker: PYTHIAS
sp.p: apart, unseen by PARMENO. Upon my faith, you villain, I'll take vengeance upon you for these sayings and doings; so that you sha'n't make sport of us with impunity. Aloud, coming forward. O, by our trust in the Gods, what a disgraceful action! O hapless young man! O wicked Parmeno, to have brought him here!

sp.speaker: PARMENO
sp.p: What's the matter?

sp.speaker: PYTHIAS
sp.p: I do pity him; and so that I mightn't see it, wretched creature that I am, I hurried away out of doors. What a dreadful example they talk of making him!

sp.speaker: PARMENO
sp.p: O Jupiter! What is this tumult? Am I then undone? I'll accost her. What's all this, Pythias? What are you saying? An example made of whom?

sp.speaker: PYTHIAS
sp.p: Do you ask the question, you most audacious fellow? You've proved the ruin of the young man whom you brought hither for the Eunuch, while you were trying to put a trick upon us.

sp.speaker: PARMENO
sp.p: How so, or what has happened? Tell me.

sp.speaker: PYTHIAS
sp.p: I'll tell you: that young woman who was to-day made a present to Thais, are you aware that she is a citizen of this place, and that her brother is a person of very high rank?

sp.speaker: PARMENO
sp.p: I didn't know that.

sp.speaker: PYTHIAS
sp.p: But so she has been discovered to be; he, unfortunate youth, has ravished her. When the brother came to know of this being done, in a most towering rage, he----

sp.speaker: PARMENO
sp.p: Did what, pray?

sp.speaker: PYTHIAS
sp.p: First, bound him in a shocking manner.

sp.speaker: PARMENO
sp.p: Bound him?

sp.speaker: PYTHIAS
sp.p: And even though Thais entreated him that he wouldn't do so----

sp.speaker: PARMENO
sp.p: What is it you tell me?

sp.speaker: PYTHIAS
sp.p: Now he is threatening that he will also do that which is usually done to ravishers; a thing that I never saw done, nor wish to.

sp.speaker: PARMENO
sp.p: With what assurance does he dare perpetrate a crime so heinous?

sp.speaker: PYTHIAS
sp.p: How "so heinous?"

sp.speaker: PARMENO
sp.p: Is it not most heinous? Who ever saw any one taken up as a ravisher in a courtesan's house?

sp.speaker: PYTHIAS
sp.p: I don't know.

sp.speaker: PARMENO
sp.p: But that you mayn't be ignorant of this, Pythias, I tell you, and give you notice that he is my master's son.

sp.speaker: PYTHIAS
sp.p: How! Prithee, is it he?

sp.speaker: PARMENO
sp.p: Don't let Thais suffer any violence to be done to him. But why don't I go in myself?

sp.speaker: PYTHIAS
sp.p: Take care, Parmeno, what you are about, lest you both do him no good and come to harm yourself; for it is their notion, that whatever has happened, has originated in you.

sp.speaker: PARMENO
sp.p: What then, wretch that I am, shall I do, or how resolve? But look, I see the old gentleman returning from the country; shall I tell him or shall I not? By my troth, I will tell him; although I am certain that a heavy punishment is in readiness for me; but it's a matter of necessity, in order that he may rescue him.

sp.speaker: PYTHIAS
sp.p: You are wise. I'm going in-doors; do you relate to him every thing exactly as it happened. Goes into the house.

sp.speaker: LACHES
sp.p: to himself. I have this advantageThis advantage: Donatus here observes that the Poet introduces Laches, as he has Parmeno just before, in a state of perfect tranquillity, that their sudden change of feeling may be the more diverting to the Audience. from my country-house being so near at hand; no weariness, either of country or of town, ever takes possession of me; when satiety begins to come on, I change my locality. But is not that our Parmeno? Surely it is he. Whom are you waiting for, Parmeno, before the door here?

sp.speaker: PARMENO
sp.p: pretends not to see him. Who is it Turning round. Oh, I'm glad that you have returned safe.

sp.speaker: LACHES
sp.p: Whom are you waiting for?

sp.speaker: PARMENO
sp.p: aside. I'm undone: my tongue cleaves to my mouth through fright.

sp.speaker: LACHES
sp.p: Why, what is it you are trembling about? Is all quite right? Tell me.

sp.speaker: PARMENO
sp.p: Master, in the first place, I would have you persuaded of what is the fact; whatever has happened in this affair has happened through no fault of mine.

sp.speaker: LACHES
sp.p: What is it?

sp.speaker: PARMENO
sp.p: Really you have reason to ask. I ought first to have told you the circumstances. Phaedria purchased a certain Eunuch, to make a present of to this woman here.

sp.speaker: LACHES
sp.p: To what woman?

sp.speaker: PARMENO
sp.p: To Thais.

sp.speaker: LACHES
sp.p: Bought? Good heavens, I'm undone! For how much?

sp.speaker: PARMENO
sp.p: Twenty minae.

sp.speaker: LACHES
sp.p: Done for, quite.

sp.speaker: PARMENO
sp.p: Then, Chaerea is in love with a certain music-girl here. Pointing to THAIS'S house.

sp.speaker: LACHES
sp.p: How! What? In love? Does he know already what a courtesan means? Is he come to town? One misfortune close upon another.

sp.speaker: PARMENO
sp.p: Master, don't look so at me; he didn't do these things by my encouragement.

sp.speaker: LACHES
sp.p: Leave off talking about yourself. If I live, you hang-dog, I'll---- But first give me an account of it, whatever it is.

sp.speaker: PARMENO
sp.p: He was taken to the house of Thais in place of the Eunuch.

sp.speaker: LACHES
sp.p: In place of the Eunuch?

sp.speaker: PARMENO
sp.p: Such is the fact. They have since apprehended him in the house as a ravisher, and bound him.

sp.speaker: LACHES
sp.p: Death!

sp.speaker: PARMENO
sp.p: Mark the assurance of courtesans.

sp.speaker: >LACH.
sp.p: Is there any other calamity or misfortune besides, that you have not told me of?

sp.speaker: PARMENO
sp.p: That's all.

sp.speaker: LACHES
sp.p: Do I delay rushing in here? Runs into the house of THAIS.

sp.speaker: PARMENO
sp.p: to himself. There's no doubt but that I shall have a heavy punishment for this affair, only that I was obliged to act thus. I'm glad of this, that some mischief will befall these women here through my agency, for the old man has, for a long time, been on the look-out for some occasionFor some occasion: We learn from Donatus that Menander was more explicit concerning the resentment of Laches against Thais, on account of her having corrupted Phaedria. to do them a bad turn; at last he has found it.

div2.stage: Enter PYTHIAS from the house of THAIS, laughing.

sp.speaker: PYTHIAS
sp.p: to herself, on entering. Never, upon my faith, for a long time past, has any thing happened to me that I could have better liked to happen, than the old gentleman just now, full of his mistake, coming into our house. I had the joke all to myself, as I knewAs I knew: She enjoyed it the more, knowing that the old man had nothing to fear, as he had just heard the fiction which she had imparted to Parmeno. Donatus observes that the terror of Laches accounts for his sudden consent to the union of Chaerea with Pamphila; for though he could not settle the matter any other way with credit, he was glad to find that his son had made an unequal match rather than endangered his life. Colman, however, observes with considerable justice: "I think Chaerea apologizes still better for this arrangement in the Scene with Thais at the opening of this Act, where he says that he is confident of obtaining his father's consent, provided Pamphila proves to be a citizen; and, indeed, the match between them is rather a reparation of an injury done to her than a degradation of himself." what it was he feared.

sp.speaker: PARMENO
sp.p: apart. Why, what's all this?

sp.speaker: PYTHIAS
sp.p: Now I'm come out to meet with Parmeno. But, prithee, where is he? Looking around.

sp.speaker: PARMENO
sp.p: apart. She's looking for me.

sp.speaker: PYTHIAS
sp.p: And there he is, I see; I'll go up to him.

sp.speaker: PARMENO
sp.p: What's the matter, simpleton? What do you mean? What are you laughing about? Still going on?

sp.speaker: PYTHIAS
sp.p: laughing. I'm dying; I'm wretchedly tired with laughing at you.

sp.speaker: PARMENO
sp.p: Why so?

sp.speaker: PYTHIAS
sp.p: Do you ask? Upon my faith, I never did see, nor shall see, a more silly fellow. Oh dear, I can not well express what amusement you've afforded in-doors. And still I formerly took you to be a clever and shrewd person. Why, was there any need for you instantly to believe what I told you? Or were you not content with the crime, which by your advice the young man had been guilty of, without betraying the poor fellow to his father as well? Why, what do you suppose his feelings must have been at the moment when his father saw him clothed in that dress? Well, do you now understand that you are done for? Laughing.

sp.speaker: PARMENO
sp.p: Hah! what is it you say, you hussy? Have you been telling me lies? What, laughing still? Does it appear so delightful to you, you jade, to be making fools of us?

sp.speaker: PYTHIAS
sp.p: laughing. Very much so.

sp.speaker: PARMENO
sp.p: Yes, indeed, if you can do it with impunity.

sp.speaker: PYTHIAS
sp.p: Exactly so.

sp.speaker: PARMENO
sp.p: By heavens, I'll repay you!

sp.speaker: PYTHIAS
sp.p: I believe you; but, perhaps, that which you are threatening, Parmeno, will need a future day; you'll be trussed up directly, for rendering a silly young man remarkable for disgraceful conduct, and then betraying him to his father; they'll both be making an example of you. Laughing.

sp.speaker: PARMENO
sp.p: I'm done for!

sp.speaker: PYTHIAS
sp.p: This reward has been found you in return for that present of yours;In return for that present of yours: By the present she means Chaerea in the disguise of the Eunuch. I'm off. Goes into the house.

sp.speaker: PARMENO
sp.p: to himself. Wretch that I am; just like a rat, this day I've come to destruction through betrayal of myself.Through betrayal of myself: Which betrays itself by its own squeaking.

sp.speaker: GNATHO
sp.p: to THRASO. Well now? With what hope, or what design, are we come hither? What do you intend to do, Thraso?

sp.speaker: THRASO
sp.p: What, I? To surrender myself to Thais, and do what she bids me.

sp.speaker: GNATHO
sp.p: What is it you say?

sp.speaker: THRASO
sp.p: Why any the less so, than Hercules served Omphale.Hercules served Omphale: He alludes to the story of Omphale, Queen of Lydia, and Hercules. Being violently in love with her, the hero laid aside his club and boar's skin, and in the habit of a woman plied the spindle and distaff with her maids. See a curious story of Omphale, Hercules, and Faunus, in the Fasti of Ovid, B. ii. l. 305. As to the reappearance of Thraso here, Colman has the following remarks: "Thraso, says Donatus, is brought back again in order to be admitted to some share in the good graces of Thais, that he may not be made unhappy at the end of the Play; but surely it is an essential part of the poetical justice of Comedy to expose coxcombs to ridicule and to punish them, though without any shocking severity, for their follies."

sp.speaker: GNATHO
sp.p: The precedent pleases me. Aside. I only wish I may see your head stroked down with a slipper;With a slipper: He doubtless alludes to the treatment of Hercules by Omphale; and, according to Lucian, there was a story that Omphale used to beat him with her slipper or sandal. On that article of dress, see the Notes to the Trinummus of Plautus, 1. 252. but her door makes a noise.

sp.speaker: THRASO

div2.stage: Enter CHAEREA from the house of THAIS, on the other side of the stage.

sp.speaker: CHAEREA
sp.p: to himself, aloud. O fellow-townsmen, is there any one alive more fortunate than me this day? Not any one, upon my faith: for clearly in me have the Gods manifested all their power, on whom, thus suddenly, so many blessings are bestowed.

sp.speaker: PARMENO
sp.p: apart. Why is he thus overjoyed?

sp.speaker: CHAEREA
sp.p: seeing PARMENO, and running up to him. O my dear Parmeno, the contriver, the beginner, the perfecter of all my delights, do you know what are my transports? Are you aware that my Pamphila has been discovered to be a citizen?

sp.speaker: PARMENO
sp.p: I have heard so.

sp.speaker: CHAEREA
sp.p: Do you know that she is betrothed to me?

sp.speaker: PARMENO
sp.p: So may the Gods bless me, happily done.

sp.speaker: GNATHO
sp.p: apart to THRASO. Do you hear what he says?

sp.speaker: CHAEREA
sp.p: And then, besides, I am delighted that my brother's mistress is secured to him; the family is united. Thais has committed herself to the patronage of my father;To the patronage of my father: It was the custom at Athens for strangers, such as Thais was, to put themselves under the protection (in clientelam) of some wealthy citizen, who, as their patron, was bound to protect them against injury. An exactly parallel case to the present is found in the Miles Gloriosus of Plautus, 1. 799, where the wealthy Periplecomenus says, "Habeo, eccillam, meam clientam, meretricem adolescentulam." "Why, look, I have one, a dependent of mine, a courtesan, a very young woman." she has put herself under our care and protection.

sp.speaker: PARMENO
sp.p: Thais, then, is wholly your brother's.

sp.speaker: CHAEREA
sp.p: Of course.

sp.speaker: PARMENO
sp.p: Then this is another reason for us to rejoice, that the Captain will be beaten out of doors.

sp.speaker: CHAEREA
sp.p: Wherever my brother is, do you take care that he hears this as soon as possible.

sp.speaker: PARMENO
sp.p: I'll go look for him at home. Goes into the house of LACHES.

sp.speaker: THRASO
sp.p: apart to GNATHO. Do you at all doubt, Gnatho, but that I am now ruined everlastingly?

sp.speaker: GNATHO
sp.p: to THRASO. Without doubt, I do think so.

sp.speaker: CHAEREA
sp.p: to himself. What am I to make mention of first, or commend in especial? Him who gave me the advice to do so, or myself, who ventured to undertake it? Or ought I to extol fortune, who has been my guide, and has so opportunely crowded into a single day events so numerous, so important; or my father's kindness and indulgence Oh Jupiter, I entreat you, do preserve these blessings unto us! Enter PHAEDRIA from the house of LACHES.

sp.speaker: PHAEDRIA
sp.p: to himself. Ye Gods, by our trust in you, what incredible things has Parmeno just related to me! But where is my brother?

sp.speaker: CHAEREA
sp.p: stepping forward. Here he is.

sp.speaker: PHAEDRIA
sp.p: I'm overjoyed.

sp.speaker: CHAEREA
sp.p: I quite believe you. There is no one, brother, more worthy to be loved than this Thais of yours: so much is she a benefactress to all our family.

sp.speaker: PHAEDRIA
sp.p: Whew! are you commending her too to me?

sp.speaker: THRASO
sp.p: apart. I'm undone; the less the hope I have, the more I am in love. Prithee, Gnatho, my hope is in you.

sp.speaker: GNATHO
sp.p: apart. What do you wish me to do?

sp.speaker: THRASO
sp.p: apart. Bring this about, by entreaties or with money, that I may at least share Thais's favors in some degree.

sp.speaker: GNATHO
sp.p: apart. It's a hard task.

sp.speaker: THRASO
sp.p: apart. If you set your mind on any thing, I know you well. If you manage this, ask me for any present you like as your reward; you shall have what you ask.

sp.speaker: GNATHO
sp.p: apart. Is it so?

sp.speaker: THRASO
sp.p: apart. It shall be so.

sp.speaker: GNATHO
sp.p: apart. If I manage this, I ask that your house, whether you are present or absent, may be open to me; that, without invitation, there may always be a place for me.

sp.speaker: THRASO
sp.p: apart. I pledge my honor that it shall be so.

sp.speaker: GNATHO
sp.p: apart. I'll set about it then.

sp.speaker: PHAEDRIA
sp.p: Who is it I hear so close at hand? Turning round. O Thraso----

sp.speaker: THRASO
sp.p: coming forward. Save you both----

sp.speaker: PHAEDRIA
sp.p: Perhaps you are not aware what has taken place here.

sp.speaker: THRASO
sp.p: I am quite aware.

sp.speaker: PHAEDRIA
sp.p: Why, then, do I see you in this neighborhood?

sp.speaker: THRASO
sp.p: Depending on your kindness.

sp.speaker: PHAEDRIA
sp.p: Do you know what sort of dependence you have? Captain, I give you notice, if ever I catch you in this street again, even if you should say to me, "I was looking for another person, I was on my road this way," you are undone.

sp.speaker: GNATHO
sp.p: Come, come, that's not handsome.

sp.speaker: PHAEDRIA
sp.p: I've said it.

sp.speaker: GNATHO
sp.p: I didn't know you gave yourself such airs.

sp.speaker: PHAEDRIA
sp.p: So it shall be.

sp.speaker: GNATHO
sp.p: First hear a few words from me; and when I have said the thing, if you approve of it, do it.

sp.speaker: PHAEDRIA
sp.p: Let's hear.

sp.speaker: GNATHO
sp.p: Do you step a little that way, Thraso. THRASO stands aside. In the firs place, I wish you both implicitly to believe me in this, that whatever I do in this matter, I do it entirely for my own sake; but if the same thing is of advantage to yourselves, it would be folly for you not to do it.

sp.speaker: PHAEDRIA
sp.p: What is it?

sp.speaker: GNATHO
sp.p: I'm of opinion that the Captain, your rival, should be received among you.

sp.speaker: PHAEDRIA
sp.p: starting. Hah!

sp.speaker: CHAEREA
sp.p: Be received?

sp.speaker: GNATHO
sp.p: to PHAEDRIA. Only consider. I'faith, Phaedria, at the free rate you are living with her, and indeed very freely you are living, you have but little to give; and it's necessary for Thais to receive a good deal. That all this may be supplied for your amour and not at your own expense, there is not an individual better suited or more fitted for your purpose than the Captain. In the first place, he both.has got enough to give, and no one does give more profusely. He is a fool, a dolt, a blockhead; night and day he snores away; and you need not fear that the lady will fall in love with him; you may easily have him discarded whenever you please.

sp.speaker: CHAEREA
sp.p: to PHAEDRIA. What shall we do?

sp.speaker: GNATHO
sp.p: And this besides, which I deem to be of even greater importance,--not a single person entertains in better style or more bountifully.

sp.speaker: CHAEREA
sp.p: It's a wonder if this sort of man can not be made use of in some way or other.

sp.speaker: PHAEDRIA
sp.p: I think so too.

sp.speaker: GNATHO
sp.p: You act properly. One thing I have still to beg of you,--that you'll receive me into your fraternity; I've been rolling that stoneBeen rolling that stone: Donatus thinks that he alludes to the story of Sisyphus, who, in the Infernal Regions, was condemned eternally to roll a stone up a hill, which, on arriving at the summit, immediately fell to the bottom. for a considerable time past.

sp.speaker: PHAEDRIA
sp.p: We admit you.

sp.speaker: CHAEREA
sp.p: And with all my heart.

sp.speaker: GNATHO
sp.p: Then I, in return for this, Phaedria, and you, Chaerea, make him over to youMake him over to you)--Ver. 1086.. "Vobis propino." The word "propino" was properly applied to the act of tasting a cup of wine, and then handing it to another; he means that he has had his taste of the Captain, and is now ready to hand him over to them. to be eaten and drunk to the dregs.

sp.speaker: CHAEREA
sp.p: Agreed.

sp.speaker: PHAEDRIA
sp.p: He quite deserves it.He quite deserves it)--Ver 1087. Cooke has the following appropriate remark: "I can not think that this Play, excellent as it is in almost all other respects, concludes consistently with the manners of gentlemen; there is a meanness in Phaedria and Chaerea consenting to take Thraso into their society, with a view of fleecing him, which the Poet should have avoided."

sp.speaker: GNATHO
sp.p: calling to THRASO. Thraso, whenever you please, step this way.

sp.speaker: THRASO
sp.p: Prithee, how goes it?

sp.speaker: GNATHO
sp.p: How? Why, these people didn't know you; after I had discovered to them your qualities, and had praised you as your actions and your virtues deserved, I prevailed upon them.

sp.speaker: THRASO
sp.p: You have managed well; I give you my best thanks. Besides, I never was any where but what all were extremely fond of me.

sp.speaker: GNATHO
sp.p: to PHAEDRIA and CHAEREA. Didn't I tell you that he was a master of the Attic elegance?

sp.speaker: PHAEDRIA
sp.p: He is no other than you mentioned. Pointing to his FATHER'S house. Walk this way. To the AUDIENCE. Fare you well, and grant us your applause.
